title.narrative: 1.3. NATIONAL INDIGENOUS POLICY

description.narrative: By 2016, the National Indigenous Policy is strengthened, with specific tools and gender sensitive methodologies to work with indigenous Early Child Development (ECD). , which contributes to Birth Registration, Child Health, Cross-Sectoral Early Childhood Development, Early Childhood Development, Early Learning, Health â€“ General, Infant And Young Child Feeding, Maternal And Newborn Health, Nutrition â€“ General, Pmtct And Infant Male Circumcision, Prevention Of Stunting And Other Forms Of Malnutrition, Social Exclusion â€“ Data And Evidence, Treatment Of Severe Acute Malnutrition. UNICEF aims to achieve this through Advocacy And Public Engagement, Operational Support To Programme Delivery, Systems Strengthening And Institution Building. This contributes to the following Country Programme result: By 2016 infant mortality, maternal mortality, chronic malnutrition and early pregnancy are reduced in Brazil, especially in the Amazon and Semiarid regions and among indigenous and afro-Brazilians and a comprehensive National Policy for Early Childhood created and implemented with good practices and lessons learned systematized and disseminated in Brazil and in other countries.

condition.narrative: Should contribute directly to results for children as outlined in the UNDAF, national results and/or UNICEF Strategic Plan and within the scope defined in the CPD, CPAP, OMP or other agreed upon programme documents

title.narrative: By 2016, the National Indigenous Policy is strengthened, with specific tools and gender sensitive methodologies to work withindigenous ECD.

description.narrative: Indigenous population continued to be a high priority to UNICEF and partners. The reduction of maternal and child mortality is a challenge and requires direct participation of local managers, indigenous women and leaders. Only intersectoral interventions can be used to change the reality of this vulnerable population. | Status:Met | As-of Date:04/01/2017

title.narrative: Gender sensitive and culturally adapted methodologies used in indigenous villages
